title: Alternative Smoothing Kernels (Continued)

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw:
I intended to update the corresponding [YTEP](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-requests/53/adding-ytep-0024-for-alternative-smoothing/diff) completely, but haven't finished it yet. For the convenience of reviewing, here I'd like to briefly talk about the main issues I've encountered so far.

* In the current smoothing operations, the kernel is not required to be normalized. But I think in the future a normalized kernel might be needed in some operations. Is it a good idea to define all the kernels normalized, considering the computation cost is low (multiplication by a constant), so they might have wider applications?

* Due to my limited knowledge of Cython, I feel my implementation (if-elif-else) of the lookup function [`get_kernel_func`](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-requests/1670/alternative-smoothing-kernels/diff#Lyt/geometry/particle_deposit.pxdT87) is not so elegant. I've been experimenting on other possibilities but haven't succeeded yet.

    * I have tried `getattr`. The problem is that, if I want to access the kernel functions this way, they must be defined as python functions, which is slow!
    * I've been thinking about using a dictionary-like data structure to store the (kernel_name, kernel_func) pair, but haven't found a good solution yet.

* For the same reason, I see potentials in improving my implementation of kernel functions.

* Would it be a good idea to move all the kernel definitions out from `yt/geometry/particle_deposit.pxd` into a new file?

* My current investigation suggests that the following functions have potential access to the smoothing kernel. Have I missed any?

    * [**deposit_simple_smooth**] `yt.geometry.particle_deposit.SimpleSmooth`: aliased as `yt.geometry.particle_deposit.deposit_simple_smooth`
    * [**volume_weighted_smooth**] `yt.geometry.particle_smooth.VolumeWeightedSmooth`: aliased as `yt.geometry.particle_smooth.volume_weighted_smooth`
    * [**density_smooth**] `yt.geometry.particle_smooth.SmoothedDensityEstimate`: aliased as `yt.geometry.particle_smooth.density_smooth`
    ___
    * [**OctreeSubset**] `yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.deposit`: could call `deposit_simple_smooth` with `method="simple_smooth"`
    * [**OctreeSubset**] `yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.smooth`: could call `volume_weighted_smooth` with `method="volume_weighted"`, or `density_smooth` with `method="density"`
    * [**OctreeSubset**] `yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.particle_operation`: could call `volume_weighted_smooth` with `method="volume_weighted"`, or `density_smooth` with `method="density"`
    * [**YTCoveringGridBase**] (see **Note 1**) `yt.data_objects.construction_data_containers.YTCoveringGridBase.deposit`: could call `deposit_simple_smooth` with `method="simple_smooth"`
    * [**AMRGridPatch**] (see **Note 1**) `yt.data_objects.grid_patch.AMRGridPatch.deposit`: could call `deposit_simple_smooth` with `method="simple_smooth"`
    * [**UnstructuredMesh**] (see **Note 1**) `yt.data_objects.unstructured_mesh.UnstructuredMesh.deposit`: could call `deposit_simple_smooth` with `method="simple_smooth"`
    * [**ARTIORootMeshSubset**] (see **Note 1** & **Note 2**) `yt.frontends.artio.data_structures.ARTIORootMeshSubset.deposit`: could call `deposit_simple_smooth` with `method="simple_smooth"`
    * **Note 1**: I suspect those grid data objects are not supposed to access the smoothing kernel.
    * **Note 2**: In this function `self.oct_handler.deposit(op, self.base_selector, pos, f64)` is called. But in other places, we have `deposit(self, positions, fields = None, method = None)`. The two forms of `deposit` seem to be incompatible.
    ___
    * [~~**add_deposited_particle_field**~~] (see **Note 3**) `yt.data_objects.static_output.Dataset.add_deposited_particle_field`: has no access to the smoothing kernel currently
    * [**add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field**] `yt.fields.particle_fields.add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field`: through `.smooth` with `method="volume_weighted"`
    * [**add_density_kernel**] (see **Note 4**) `yt.fields.particle_fields.add_density_kernel`: through `.particle_operation` with `method="density"`
    * **Note 3**: It's interesting to compare the docstring of `add_deposited_particle_field` and that of `OctreeSubset.deposit`. More methods are allowed for the latter one, while the latter one is supposed to be called by the former one, which means the extra methods are wasted, right? Is there a reason I missed that only three methods are allowed in `add_deposited_particle_field` while more are defined in `particle_deposit`?
    * **Note 4**: `add_density_kernel` might be dead code. See the comments below.
content.html:
I intended to update the corresponding YTEP completely, but haven't finished it yet. For the convenience of reviewing, here I'd like to briefly talk about the main issues I've encountered so far.

  • In the current smoothing operations, the kernel is not required to be normalized. But I think in the future a normalized kernel might be needed in some operations. Is it a good idea to define all the kernels normalized, considering the computation cost is low (multiplication by a constant), so they might have wider applications?

  • Due to my limited knowledge of Cython, I feel my implementation (if-elif-else) of the lookup function get_kernel_func is not so elegant. I've been experimenting on other possibilities but haven't succeeded yet.

    • I have tried getattr. The problem is that, if I want to access the kernel functions this way, they must be defined as python functions, which is slow!
    • I've been thinking about using a dictionary-like data structure to store the (kernel_name, kernel_func) pair, but haven't found a good solution yet.

  • For the same reason, I see potentials in improving my implementation of kernel functions.

  • Would it be a good idea to move all the kernel definitions out from yt/geometry/particle_deposit.pxd into a new file?

  • My current investigation suggests that the following functions have potential access to the smoothing kernel. Have I missed any?

    • [deposit_simple_smooth] yt.geometry.particle_deposit.SimpleSmooth: aliased as yt.geometry.particle_deposit.deposit_simple_smooth
    • [volume_weighted_smooth] yt.geometry.particle_smooth.VolumeWeightedSmooth: aliased as yt.geometry.particle_smooth.volume_weighted_smooth
    • [density_smooth] yt.geometry.particle_smooth.SmoothedDensityEstimate: aliased as yt.geometry.particle_smooth.density_smooth
    • [OctreeSubset] yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.deposit: could call deposit_simple_smooth with method="simple_smooth"
    • [OctreeSubset] yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.smooth: could call volume_weighted_smooth with method="volume_weighted", or density_smooth with method="density"
    • [OctreeSubset] yt.data_objects.octree_subset.OctreeSubset.particle_operation: could call volume_weighted_smooth with method="volume_weighted", or density_smooth with method="density"
    • [YTCoveringGridBase] (see Note 1) yt.data_objects.construction_data_containers.YTCoveringGridBase.deposit: could call deposit_simple_smooth with method="simple_smooth"
    • [AMRGridPatch] (see Note 1) yt.data_objects.grid_patch.AMRGridPatch.deposit: could call deposit_simple_smooth with method="simple_smooth"
    • [UnstructuredMesh] (see Note 1) yt.data_objects.unstructured_mesh.UnstructuredMesh.deposit: could call deposit_simple_smooth with method="simple_smooth"
    • [ARTIORootMeshSubset] (see Note 1 & Note 2) yt.frontends.artio.data_structures.ARTIORootMeshSubset.deposit: could call deposit_simple_smooth with method="simple_smooth"
    • Note 1: I suspect those grid data objects are not supposed to access the smoothing kernel.
    • Note 2: In this function self.oct_handler.deposit(op, self.base_selector, pos, f64) is called. But in other places, we have deposit(self, positions, fields = None, method = None). The two forms of deposit seem to be incompatible.
    • [add_deposited_particle_field] (see Note 3) yt.data_objects.static_output.Dataset.add_deposited_particle_field: has no access to the smoothing kernel currently
    • [add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field] yt.fields.particle_fields.add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field: through .smooth with method="volume_weighted"
    • [add_density_kernel] (see Note 4) yt.fields.particle_fields.add_density_kernel: through .particle_operation with method="density"
    • Note 3: It's interesting to compare the docstring of add_deposited_particle_field and that of OctreeSubset.deposit. More methods are allowed for the latter one, while the latter one is supposed to be called by the former one, which means the extra methods are wasted, right? Is there a reason I missed that only three methods are allowed in add_deposited_particle_field while more are defined in particle_deposit?
    • Note 4: add_density_kernel might be dead code. See the comments below.

content.raw: After further investigation, I think `add_density_kernel` (defined in `yt/fields/particle_fields.py`) is not actually used by other codes to add fields. And this function's behavior is weird. It uses the field name (ptype, "smoothed_density") which does not conform to the naming scheme.
content.html: After further investigation, I think add_density_kernel (defined in yt/fields/particle_fields.py) is not actually used by other codes to add fields. And this function's behavior is weird. It uses the field name (ptype, "smoothed_density") which does not conform to the naming scheme.

content.raw: Just jumping in without full context, but it might just be dead code that isn't used anywhere.  I'm in the middle of cleaning up the repository to get rid of dead code like this, but haven't gotten to yt.fields yet :)
content.html: Just jumping in without full context, but it might just be dead code that isn't used anywhere. I'm in the middle of cleaning up the repository to get rid of dead code like this, but haven't gotten to yt.fields yet :)

We talked about this at the PR review hangout and we see two open issues:

1. Some of the answer tests are failing
2. The PR is pointing at the stable branch rather than the yt branch.

Do you want some help in resolving these issues? I'm happy to chat with you in realtime or over e-mail.

content.raw:
No time pressure, please work on this whenever you have time.

For 1, take a look at the recently updated docs on how to run answer tests: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/developing/testing.html#answer-testing

If you want to run the tests locally you'll need to follow that guide, generating local answers on the current development tip and then run the answer tests on the PR using the locally generated answers. I'd suggest only running the OWLS tests, since the Tipsy tests take a little while to run.

For 2, yup, specifically the head marked `[development]` on the dropdown list.

content.raw: For 2, it seems I cannot make the change. The problem is that when I try to edit the PR, I cannot choose the bookmark in my repo (there is only one option, `yt`). So even when i switch to `[development]`, it says 'No commits on yt that aren't on a5d76f647fbb'. So I cannot update my PR.

content.raw:
For 1

* For OWLS tests, the errors are all `YTNoOldAnswer: There is no old answer available.`, which I don't know how to handle.

* For Tipsy tests, there are `AssertionError`s, of which I haven't dug out the causes yet. But it's so weird to me because all existing codes should behave exactly the same with the changes in this PR.

So I'm wondering if the answer tests have changed after the commit this PR is based on? I'm trying to test the idea by switching to previous commits and do the answer tests from there. But the nosetests stopped working somehow. I'm trying to solve that currently.

content.raw: You might need to decline and reissue your PR. There is a bitbucket bug that causes behavior similar to what you're seeing.

content.raw:
The `YTNoOldAnswer` are probably caused by not generating answers with `--answer-store` on a "known good" changeset before comparing on your PR.

For the `AssertionErrors`, can you share the full error along with tracebacks in a pastebin?

Maybe this weekend I will try to reproduce the test failures and take a look at what's happening here. No promises though....

content.raw: For the last step, you want to do `hg merge a5d76f6`, not `hg up`. The commit "a5d76f6" is the current upstream head.

content.raw: Haven't handled conflicts before, I need to learn how to do it.
content.html: Haven't handled conflicts before, I need to learn how to do it.

content.raw:
Sorry this has been so complicated!

In my opinion the easiest way to do this is with conflict markers. You'll want your hgrc too look like this:

```
[ui]
merge = internal:merge3
mergemarkers = detailed
```

This will give you conflict markers that dilineate your version, the version you're merging with, and the "base" version which is the last common ancestor.

If you're already in the middle of the merge, you can abort it and start over with `hg update -C <your_pr_head>`, where <your_pr_head> is the commit at the tip of this PR. You can then fix the merge conflicts. When you're done with each file, mark it as resolved with `hg resolve --mark path/to/file`.

I'm on slack if you want to have realtime advice.
content.html:

In my opinion the easiest way to do this is with conflict markers. You'll want your hgrc too look like this:

[ui]
merge = internal:merge3
mergemarkers = detailed

This will give you conflict markers that dilineate your version, the version you're merging with, and the "base" version which is the last common ancestor.

If you're already in the middle of the merge, you can abort it and start over with hg update -C <your_pr_head>, where <your_pr_head> is the commit at the tip of this PR. You can then fix the merge conflicts. When you're done with each file, mark it as resolved with hg resolve --mark path/to/file.

I'm on slack if you want to have realtime advice.

Corresponding YTEP [PR #53](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-requests/53/adding-ytep-0024-for-alternative-smoothing/diff).
